text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen today I'm 
going to make bped yang so bped is duck and yang is

to roast so this is basically Chinese Rostock 
but done Thai style which means that it comes

with the most delicious gravy ever that you're 
gonna want to put on everything this is inspired

by a popular dish at a hotpot restaurant chain in 
thailand called MK tsuki if you live in thailand

you've been there you might have had but ya had MK 
because it is super super popular everybody orders

it who go there but instead of doing a whole 
duck we're just gonna do duck breast makes it a

lot more practical for home cooking alright let's 
get started so I've got two duck breasts here and

the first thing you want to do is you wanna trim 
the silver skin that's on the backside because

that stuff if you leave it on it's quite chewy 
it doesn't cook down so here's what you do I'm

actually gonna first remove the tender so this 
is the tender so the same as chicken tender but

doc has a chewy connective tissue right here 
that runs through it so I'm just gonna remove

it I'll still cook it up and snack on it but I 
don't want to leave it on the breast I'm using

a boning knife you can use a small paring knife 
something with a with a pointy tip and just try

to get under and get out as much of it as you can 
without sacrificing the meat there you go then

also on this side you see some silver skin there 
now there is some silver skin that actually runs

into the meat nothing you can do about that so you 
can like I usually find a couple pieces that's a

bit chewy but you know what you're gonna do you 
remove as much as you can that's on the outside

and then this extra fat you want to remove that 
as well and then we're just gonna trim off excess

skin here just because when we go to fry it the 
the skin that hangs over will touch the marinate

and then burn around the edges so just want to 
make a nice neat piece you can save that and fry

it up into crispy duck skin as well you don't have 
to throw and now on the other side I'm gonna score

the skin break the skin open don't get to the meat 
your goal here is to open it up so that the fat

can render out more easily and I'm doing small 
small scores here because then the score marks

that's where I'm gonna slice my duck then it's a 
lot easier for me I don't have to slice through

cooked crispy skin okay that's good so now I'm 
gonna make the dry wrap for the meat really really

simple I've got some brown sugar here I'm using 
light brown sugar but you can do dark brown sugar

and some salt and then this is the key important 
ingredient here is five-spice powder it's a

mixture of different spices I do have a recipe for 
it if you want to make it at home or you can just

buy five-spice powder from the store and I'm also 
gonna add some ginger powder you can use grated

ginger but then I find keeping this dry makes it 
easier to apply if you use grated ginger then it

becomes sort of a wet pace and it's a little more 
tricky to apply but still works all the same and

try your best to not get this rub on the skin just 
because there is sugar in it and then we're gonna

sear the skin and so the sugar will burn I always 
manage to get some on the skin so but that's okay

just do your best if you were to do a whole duck 
you would just rub this rub rub this rub into the

cavity of the duck and then with a little bit that 
I have left here I'm gonna just marinate my tender

so I can snack on them later again trying to not 
contaminate my skin so rest this up here for now

I'm gonna flip these so you will notice that most 
Chinese barbecue duck will have a red tint to the

skin and that is nothing mysterious other than 
just some red food coloring you don't have to

add this if you don't want to but for the sake of 
curry recreating the look I'm gonna add some so I

just have just a TSP of water and I'm just gonna 
do a couple of drops of red food coloring and I'm

also just going to add a Touch assault to season 
the skin you don't have to I've done it with and

without but now that I remember why not so I'm 
gonna stir this until the salt is dissolved and

we'll brush this on the duck skin and you can 
add as much of the color as you like if you

want a more intense red now we're gonna let this 
marinate for at least 45 minutes uncovered because

I want the skin to dry as much as possible so 
you're just gonna do it for for 45 minutes put

a fan to it leave it outside totally fine or if 
you want to do it for up to a whole day put it

in the fridge don't cover it so the more the skin 
dries the crispier they will become when we go to

cook it so while we wait we're gonna make the duck 
gravy which is what makes this Thai style because

if you go to a Chinese restaurant here their duck 
doesn't come with this gravy I'm telling you this

you're gonna want to put it on everything it's 
so delicious and you can make it separately and

put it on other meats too if you want okay so 
we're gonna start with our Sam glue or three

friends which are white peppercorns garlic and 
cilantro stems as you've seen me make before so

peppercorns first if you're making this for kids 
I would cut the amount of pepper by about half I

like it a little peppery but it might be a little 
too spicy and then garlic cilantro stems and we're

also gonna add some ginger some chopped ginger 
this is the Chinese part of this recipe get that

into a paste okay so now that it's a fine paste 
I'm gonna add another important ingredient here

which is thought deal or fermented soybean paste 
that we use in Thai cuisine if you don't have this

you can also use miso use half the amount and 
add a little extra water and then because that

deal has some whole soybeans in it I'm gonna mash 
it you can also use the Korean fermented soybean

paste as well as a substitute five-spice powder 
again very very important ingredient alright to

the pot so I'm gonna saute the pace that 
we just made with a little bit of oil here

so keep sauteing that on low heat until it sort 
of dries up thickens a little bit start to smell

really good now it's really aromatic its dried 
up I'm gonna deglaze with some chicken stock and

for some richness coconut milk no no what's this 
doing up here I'm gonna season it with some soy

sauce and now I'm gonna switch weapon to a whisk 
so I can break up all the lumps to a mini risk

and now for a nice color I'm gonna add some black 
soy sauce you can also do dark soy sauce and you

can just adjust the color to taste it can be a 
little darker a little later up to you and one

of the most important ingredients is honey because 
this is gonna be sort of a salty sweet gravy and

duck and honey flavor match made in heaven now I'm 
gonna let that simmer for about five minutes let

the flavors mingle and marry and then we will 
do our final adjustment all right so it's been

about five minutes I did add a little extra black 
soy sauce to adjust the color a little bit it's

totally up to you I'm gonna turn this off and add 
some toasted white sesame seeds and I'm gonna do

final taste testing oh by the way I did crush the 
sesame seeds just gently in the mortar and pestle

just to break up the aroma release the aroma a 
little bit perfect yes that is exactly exactly

where I want it all right so the gravy is done 
you can keep this in the fridge it'll last like

a couple of weeks easy now let's fry up the duck 
so with the duck what I'm gonna do is I'm gonna

dry off the marinade from the bottom side of the 
meat so I'll pick that up and put it on this paper

towel here and again you want to be really careful 
not to let the marinade touch the skin oh don't

forget I just forgot I put the tender back here I 
need to take that out there you go plop that there

now we're gonna sear the duck before we roast them 
I'm gonna turn the heat on just medium you don't

want to go super high because you want to give 
the duck skin time to render out the fat and we're

just gonna sear the skin at this point no oil 
needed there's gonna be so much duck fat coming

out of the skin you will have oil in no time and 
it doesn't need to sizzle again we don't want to

burn the skin before the fat has time to render 
that's why we're not doing high heat searing here

there we go and slowly you'll start to hear that 
sizzling okay so I've got quite a lot of duck fat

now what I'm gonna do actually it's not done yet 
but I'm gonna just pour off this fat and keep it

so that I can use it for cooking later on and if 
I let it sort of hang out it might eventually burn

carefully pour it into a bowl without losing hey 
duck here so with the food coloring it's really

hard to tell what color the skin actually is but 
I'm just going buy something like that okay the

skin is now clearly thinner it has lost a lot of 
fat I'm done with that and I'm gonna transfer it

onto my baking sheet which I have lined with foil 
for easier cleaning and see see you go talking

about the edges catching the marinade and then 
burning like it's totally fine it's charred it's

character but try not to get that like all over 
the skin okay so this is gonna go now into a 400

degree oven I like it medium doneness so I like 
to do it at about 12 minutes in Asia they always

do duck well done so that you might need to do 
15 to 18 minutes depending on the size but it's

up to you at this point you can cook it super rare 
if you like it that way but I'm new to twelve so

one piece of my dog is significantly larger than 
the other so I think I might have to pull one and

then put the other one back in so I'm just gonna 
Tek temperature of the little one for now I'm 135

which is perfect that's exactly what I want 135 
we'll get you about medium this one's still 125

so I'm gonna put the big one back in and pull the 
little one out on to something before you cut into

the dock let it rest for at least I like to do 10 
minutes but even your a rush five minutes will be

fine but otherwise you cut it and if the meat is 
still piping hot it'll push out all the juices and

the meat will be dry okay so let's see what this 
does oh my God look at that perfect pinkness which

is by the way so uh nation of me to cook duck to 
pinkness but it's what I prefer so that's what

we're gonna do and then those score marks that we 
made serves perfectly as where you will cut and

you will notice that the score marks are now about 
half the width as they were when we originally

scored it so keep that in mind - oh so good look 
at that perfect pinkness super juicy super moist

pop that onto my serving plate arrange it let's 
do let's do two rows we're going to then pour the

gravy all over it and you can pour it over a pour 
it around here you can look at it this way much

nicer what I actually like to do is I douse the 
gravy all over it and then as it sits it kind of

absorbs that flavor even more and it becomes 
more delicious the nice hot jasmine rice yes
gravy

that's five-spice powder aroma and the white 
pepper that is what you're smelling up front

so good I must take another bite right away 
that duck is tender and juicy and flavorful

but really the sauce makes it there's there's 
nothing quite like that I can describe it to

you it's just a really aromatic gravy that's 
a little rich from the coconut milk a touch a

kick from this from the white pepper and you just 
have to try it if you don't want to do jack make

the sauce and put it on chicken oh yeah okay make 
the sauce put on something so I hope you give this

a try the recipe as always will be on hot Thai 
Kitchen calm when you make it send me a photo on

Facebook Twitter or Instagram and if you haven't 
expected the show make sure you do so you don't
